data.text: Contents
Introduction

The Health and Social Care Act 2012 requires healthcare providers to securely maintain accurate, complete and detailed records for patients and service users. Other legislation, such as the Freedom of Information Act 2000, requires information to be made available through good records management. The Limitation Act 1980 provides the statutory timeframe for claims to be made. In the case of clinical negligence claims, this is defined as 3 years from the date of the indexed incident, or 3 years after a child's th Birthday. In respect of contractual disputes, a claim will be statute barred if it is not lodged within 6 years of the cause of action. There are various caveats to these dates, and in some cases the date of limitation can be extended by agreement or court approval. Refer to sections 11, 12, 13, 14 and  of the Limitations Act 1980.

The NHS Records Management Code of Practice  defines the management responsibilities regarding the retention and destruction of clinical records, including specific organisational responsibilities, activities and training for designated staff with responsibility for records management.
The Data Protection Act  General Data Protection Regulations (GDPR) principles require records to be destroyed after a designated retention period unless they are of clinical significance.

BS10008-1:2020 Evidential Weight and Legal Admissibility of Electronic Information outlines best practice for the implementation and operation of electronic information management systems, including storage and transfer of information and migrating paper records to digital files. It also gives guidelines for managing the availability and accessibility of any records that could be required as legal evidence.

ISO15489-1:2016 Information and Documentation – Records Management – Part 1: Concepts and Principles defines the concepts and principles from which approaches to the creation, capture and management of records are developed, including policies, assigned responsibilities, monitoring and training supporting effective management of records.

There are a range of sanctions if organisations cannot evidence satisfactory records management arrangements, ranging from regulatory conditions or monetary penalties issued by the Information Commissioners Office (ICO), formals warnings or professional de-registration (temporary or permanent).

It is important that patient health records are actively maintained. This applies to paper records and those in cloud based solutions. There should be a full inventory of what is held where, the retention period applied to each record, a disposal log and evidence of secure disposal of records and information.

Patient health records should be appraised when they reach the end of the retention period for disposal, or to provide instruction for continued storage, secure, evidenced destruction or transfer to the local Place of Deposit.
If an approved offsite company is used for destruction, they must be able to evidence that they meet the necessary requirements of ISO15489-1:2016.
Scope
The scope of this document includes:
Health records of patients treated by the Trust;
Health records of patients treated on behalf of the Trust in private healthcare settings;
Health records where there is integration with health services e.g. jointly held records and local health and care records;
The process by which patient health records are retained, reviewed, scanned and destroyed.
The scope of this document does not include:
Staff records;
Complaints records;
Corporate records;
The management of digital records held on clinical systems

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust

The Information Governance and Cyber Security Steering Group is responsible for monitoring health records management including the retention and destruction processes in accordance with GDPR requirements.

The Chief Executive has responsibility for ensuring staff conform to the standards required for patient records management set out in the NHS Records Management Code of Practice 2020 and that all IT systems conform to BS10008-1:2020.

The Senior Information Risk Owner (SIRO) has responsibility for the managerial focus for records in all formats throughout their lifecycle, from creation to ultimate disposal, and report on such matters to the Trust Board.

The Chief Medical Officer is responsible for ensuring medical and surgical staff are appropriately trained and competent to carry out their designated duties and are fully aware of their personal responsibilities in respect of record keeping and records management, referring to relevant standard setting bodies e.g. Royal Colleges and General Medical Council.

The Chief Nursing Officer and Caldicott Guardian is responsible for ensuring all nursing and ward staff are appropriately trained and competent to carry out their designated duties, and fully are fully aware of their personal responsibilities in respect of record keeping and records management, referring to relevant standard setting bodies e.g. Nursing and Midwifery Council and Royal College of Nursing. As Caldicott Guardian is the senior person responsible for protecting the confidentiality of people's health and care information and making sure it is used properly.

The Deputy Director of Clinical Coding, Data Quality and Health Records is responsible for the overall management of the health records functions, including ensuring staff are appropriately trained in the management of health records and competent to carry out their duties. They are also responsible for authorising the destruction process whether managed in house or by offsite company.

Site Health Records Managers are responsible for the day to day management of the Health Records Team including delivering appropriate training, ensuring staff are competent to carry out their designated duties and are fully aware of their personal responsibilities in respect of record keeping and records management. They are also responsible for ensuring policies, procedures and guidelines are kept up to date in line with national policy as well as managing the destruction process whether managed in house or by offsite company.

All staff, whether working with health records must be aware of their responsibilities regarding record keeping and records management. Training must include the use of electronic records systems and complemented by organisational policies, procedures and guidance documentation.
Procedure for destruction of legacy records
This section details the procedure for the appraisal process and the physical destruction of legacy paper health records that are at the end of their standard retention period.
The procedure does not include the appraisal and destruction of digital health records which should form part of electronic systems functionality.
Appraisal
5.3.1 Recall appropriate records/boxes of records from storage.
5.3.2 Review records within box and split between adult or child e.g. if patient was treated as a child and still under  years of age.

5.3.3 If patient was a child when treated and is still under the age of 25 years, rebox the record with revised retention period and return to storage. Update appropriate Patient Administration System tracking with details of new box and barcode number.

5.3.4 If the record relates to an adult and does not contain any other reason for extended retention in accordance with the Retention Schedule of the NHS Records Management Code of Practice  the contents can be scanned and destroyed.

5.3.5 Where there is justification in additional retention of a record, this can be extended up to  years from the last date at which content was added. For maternity records, where there is already a longer retention period, these may be retained up to a further 25 years.

5.3.6 If the record requires additional retention rebox the record with revised retention period and return to storage. Update appropriate Patient Administration System tracking with details of new box and barcode number.
Procedure for day to day current business

Documentation that has been created as a result of an outpatient appointment or an inpatient  episode  is  returned  to  the  Health  Records  Centres  for  scanning  and uploading to view in the Acute Care Portal.
Once scanned and the image/s quality checked, the original paper documents will be stored on site for a period of one month before being destroyed via the approved Trust waste contractor.
Destruction

7.1.1 If the record does not require additional retention as it has reached the end of its retention  period,  the  contents  should  be  scanned  on  to  the  Trust's  electronic document management system in case it may be required to support a National Inquiry e.g. The Independent Inquiry into Child Sex Abuse, or the Infected Blood Inquiry. Scanned documents are admissible as evidence and managed in line with BS10008.
7.1.2 Once scanned and the image/s quality checked, the original paper documents can be destroyed via an approved Trust waste contractor.
7.1.3 Update appropriate tracking system with details of date of destruction and where appropriate, change the volumes status and enter comments in appropriate field.

7.1.4 Maintain a list of files (Excel or similar) listing the date the record was appraised and by whom, the date that the record was destroyed and the details of the Destruction Certificate that corresponds to that file.

7.1.5 Arrange for the collection of confidential waste bins and request a copy of the Destruction Certificate to evidence date of destruction and update the list of records destroyed with the certificate information.
Using an offsite company

If an offsite company is used for the review, scanning and destruction of records, the Trust is responsible for ensuring that the company meets the necessary requirements of ISO15489-1:2016 and can evidence this. This evidence should be checked as part of due diligence.
Destruction provider companies must provide a certificate of destruction which must then be linked to a list of records to provide clear evidence that particular records have been destroyed.
Training requirements

Staff responsible for the appraisal and destruction of records will be provided with training by the Health Records Management Team, and will be supervised for a period of time to ensure that understand the nuances of retention periods.

Where an offsite company is used, training will be provided to specifically identified members of their staff, and will be supervised for a period of time. The Trust will undertake additional due diligence checks. No other persons will be allowed to undertake this task until they have had appropriate training by Trust Health Records management.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Information Governance and Cyber Security Steering Group which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Health Records Service of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
